presentation.title: Carbon assessment
presentation.runninghead: The values accrued by any beneficiary of CO2 capture
presentation.description: The values accrued by any beneficiary of CO2 capture

page.title: Total Sequestration
page.name: C removed
page.description:
Total CO2 sequestered. The amount of carbon taken up by vegetation and soils and added to biotic and soil carbon stocks. This is the quantity available for mitigating anthropogenic carbon emissions.

Role in models

This map is the most relevant output of the ARIES carbon model. The value of the area in mitigating the adverse effects of climate change is directly proportional to the level of carbon sequesterd by vegetation and soil.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tonnes of carbons sequestered per hectare per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the distribution probability of the amount of carbon.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server when the area was selected.
page.runninghead: Tonnes of C sequestered by vegetation and soils

page.name: Stored Carbon Release
page.title: Release of stored carbon
page.description: The total emissions of carbon from the landscape, i.e., due to fire, deforestation, or other land use-land cover change.
page.runninghead: The total emissions of carbon from the landscape, i.e., due to fire, deforestation, or other land use-land cover change.

page.name: CO2 Emitters
page.description: Emitters benefit under a scenario of compensation
page.runninghead: Emitters benefit under a scenario of compensation

page.title: C/N ratio in soil
page.name: C/N ratio
page.runninghead: Tonnes of C sequestered by vegetation and soils

page.name: Summer High Winter Low
page.description: The difference between mean summer high and winter low temperatures can be a meaningful predictor of net primary production.
page.runninghead: The difference between mean summer high and winter low temperatures.

page.name: Successional Stage
page.description: The stage of vegetation regrowth following a major disturbance event. The rate succession will vary widely in different plant communities and regions of the world.
page.runninghead: The stage of vegetation growth influences CO2 uptake.

page.name: Percent Vegetation Cover
page.title: % vegetative cover
page.description: Percent vegetative cover. Different vegetation types also have different rooting depths, root densities, and transpiration rates, affecting their ability to aid in infiltration of water and/or slowing of wind and wave energy.

page.name: Degradation Status
page.description: Forests in Madagascar are noted as degraded or not degraded.
page.runninghead: Forests in Madagascar are noted as degraded or not degraded.

page.name: Slope
page.description: Soil on slopes can be washed away.
page.runninghead: Soil on slopes can be washed away.

page.name: Vegetation Type
page.description: Different species and groups of plant species have different carbon sequestration rates and different capacity to store carbon (Jenkins et al. 2003).
page.runninghead: Vegetation type is a factor in defining sequestration and storage capacities.

page.name: Soil Oxygen Conditions
page.description: The presence of oxygen (aerobic environment) allows respiration to take place, where sugars are oxidized and CO2 is produced. In anaerobic environments, methanogenesis may occur. Falling water tables in wetlands can also allow oxidation of soils, reducing their carbon storage.
page.runninghead: The presence of oxygen allows CO2-producing respiration to take place.
